Various font features of theamsmath package

text-unit.text: In theamsmath package\boldsymbol is used for getting individual bold mathsymbols and bold Greek letters—everything in math except for letters of theLatin alphabet, where you’d use\mathbf. For example,
looks like this:

If a bold version of a particular symbol doesn’t exist in the available fonts, then\boldsymbol can’t be used to make that symbol bold. At the present time, thismeans that\boldsymbol can’t be used with symbols from themsam andmsbmfonts, among others. In some cases, poor man’s bold (\pmb) can be used insteadof\boldsymbol:
text-unit.Formula:
\begin {equation*}\frac {\partial x}{\partial y} \pmb {\bigg \vert } \frac {\partial y}{\partial z}\end {equation*}
∂x∂y⃓⃓⃓⃓ ∂y∂z File name:testmath.tex File name:testmath.tex File name:testmath.tex

∑︁
and

TEX
book.

text-unit.text: \iint,\iiint, and\iiiint give multiple integral signs with the spacing be-tween them nicely adjusted, in both text and display style. \idotsint givestwo integral signs with dots between them.

LATEX
provides\overrightarrow and\overleftarrow).

text-unit.text: These all scale properly in subscript sizes:

Normally you need only type\dots for ellipsis dots in a math formula. Themain exception is when the dots fall at the end of the formula; then you needto specify one of\dotsc (series dots, after a comma),\dotsb (binary dots, forbinary relations or operators),\dotsm (multiplication dots), or\dotsi (dotsafter an integral). For example, the input
produces

$A_1A_2\dotsm $
A1A2···
, and the infinite integral

This double accent operation is complicated and tends to slow down the pro-cessing of a
LATEX
file.

text-unit.text: The usual notation for binomials is similar to the fraction concept, so it has asimilar command\binom with two arguments. Example:
There are also abbreviations
for the commonly needed constructions

The generalized fraction command\genfrac provides full access to the six
TEX
fraction primitives:
The continued fraction
can be obtained by typing
Left or right placement of any of the numerators is accomplished by using\cfrac[l] or\cfrac[r] instead of\cfrac.

Inamsmath there are optional argumentst andb for the plain
TEX
command\smash, because sometimes it is advantageous to be able to ‘smash’ only the topor only the bottom of something while retaining the natural depth or height. Inthe formula
$X_j=(1/\sqrt {\smash [b]{\lambda _j}})X_j'$
Xj= (1/√λj)X′j
\smash[b] has been used to limit the size of theradical symbol.

Without the use of\smash[b] the formula would have appeared thus:
$X_j=(1/\sqrt {\lambda _j})X_j'$
Xj=(1/√︁λj)X′j
, with the radical extending to encompass the depth of the subscript
$j$
j
.
‘Cases’ constructions like the following can be produced using thecases envi-ronment.
Notice the use of\text and the embedded math.
Here are samples of the matrix environments,\matrix,\pmatrix,\bmatrix,\Bmatrix,\vmatrix and\Vmatrix:
To produce a small matrix suitable for use in text, use thesmallmatrixenvironment.

To show the effect of the matrix on the surrounding lines of a paragraph, weput it here:
$\bigl ( \begin {smallmatrix} a&b\\ c&d \end {smallmatrix} \bigr )$
(︁abcd)︁
and follow it with enough text to ensure that there will be atleast one full line below the matrix.
\hdotsfor{number} produces a row of dots in a matrix spanning the givennumber of columns:
The spacing of the dots can be varied through use of a square-bracket option,for example,\hdotsfor[1.5]{3}. The number in square brackets will be usedas a multiplier; the normal value is 1.
The\substack command can be used to produce a multiline subscript or su-perscript: for example
produces a two-line subscript underneath the sum:
A slightly more generalized form is thesubarray environment which allows youto specify that each line should be left-aligned instead of centered, as here:

and now in\Large size:

text-unit.text: Note: Starting on this page, vertical rules are added at themargins so that the positioning of various display elementswith respect to the margins can be seen more clearly.
Thesplit environment is not an independent environment but should be usedinside something else such asequation oralign.

If there is not enough room for it, the equation number for asplit will beshifted to the previous line, when equation numbers are on the left; the numbershifts down to the next line when numbers are on the right.

Align and split within gather

text-unit.text: When using thealign environment within thegather environment, one or theother, or both, should be unnumbered (using the* form); numbering both theouter and inner environment would cause a conflict.
